qas.question: What commodity was Houston known for in 1860?

context: By 1860, Houston had emerged as a commercial and <b9_0>railroad hub<b9_0/> for the export of <a0_0><b5_0>cotton<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Railroad spurs from the Texas inland converged in Houston, where they met <a1_0><b6_0>rail lines<b6_0/><a1_0/> to the ports of Galveston and Beaumont. During the American Civil War, Houston served as a headquarters for <a2_0><b7_0>General John Bankhead Magruder<b7_0/><a2_0/>, who used the city as an organization point for the <a3_0>Battle of Galveston<a3_0/>. After the <b8_0>Civil War<b8_0/>, Houston businessmen initiated efforts to widen the city's extensive system of bayous so the city could accept more commerce between downtown and the nearby port of Galveston. By 1890, Houston was the <a4_0>railroad center of Texas<a4_0/>.
